text: The Yakima Valley is known for growing hops.
75% of the United States' hops are grown here.
This is Perrault Farms, where fourth-generation hops farmer Jason Perrault is leading the way on new hops varieties and boosting the trend of fresh hop beers.
It's the first day of harvest and that means brewers are starting to make beers with fresh hops.
Fresh hop beers use hops harvested from the field that morning to create aromatic hop-forward beers you can only get during the harvest season.

Jason Perrault
CEO & Head Breeder, Yakima Chief Hops

title: Harvesting
text: Hop vines are cut from their trellises and hauled to the harvester by trucks.
The vines are placed in the harvester where they are cut and the hop cones are sorted from the stems and leaves.
Usually the hops would then be sent to the kiln where they are dried to about 10 percent moisture content.

title: Fresh Hops
text: But for brewers to pick up fresh, or "wet," hops, they are diverted here where they can fill up bags or boxes to transport back to their brewery immediately.
This is Steve Luke from Cloudburst Brewing. He's known for making inventive, single-batch beers, especially hop-forward India Pale Ales. Cloudburst is planning to make 8 fresh hop beers this year.
